content.text: Surfaces in ACSS are custom background images, textures, patterns, or gradients that you want to be able to easily reuse throughout your project.

content.title: Name
content.tooltip: Optional: Name your surface. This will also create a custom utility class .surface-[name].

content.title: Background Color
content.tooltip: Background color will only display if your asset has transparency or if your asset fails to load (fallback).

content.title: Surface Asset
content.tooltip: The asset of your surface can be a url(), gradient, or CSS pattern. Input accepts any valid background-image value.

content.title: Asset is URL
content.tooltip: If your asset is a url, turn this on.

content.title: Color Relationship
content.tooltip: Automatically control foreground color using Automatic Color Relationships. Choose the style that describes your surface.

content.text: If your surface supports animation, you can animate it here. Your keyframes for the animation must be defined in custom CSS.

content.title: Animation
content.tooltip: Any valid CSS animation property. This will animate the surface as long as you've defined your animation keyframes in custom CSS.

content.text: You can add an overlay to your surface that won't affect foreground elements. This can be used to darken or lighten your surface or apply a cool effect.

content.title: Overlay
content.tooltip: Must be a linear gradient function! Use transparency values to retain the surface's original effect.

content.text: Basic overlays are simple single-color overlays that can be applied to any element using the .overlay or .overlay--[color] classes.

content.title: Enable Basic Overlays
content.tooltip: Enable basic overlay functionality.

content.text: If there are conflicts with other utilities or styling, you can choose which pseudo-element to use for the overlay.

content.title: Pseudo Element
content.tooltip: Choose which pseudo-element to use for the overlay.

content.text: Custom overlays are more complex, reusable overlay effects that use images, gradients, or CSS patterns. You can define up to five of them here.

content.title: Name
content.tooltip: Optional: Name your overlay. This will create a custom utility class .overlay-[name].

content.title: Background Color
content.tooltip: The background color of the overlay – mostly used as a fallback, but can also be used to blend with your advanced overlay background (see below).

content.title: Background Type
content.tooltip: Choose whether your background is an image or a gradient/pattern.

content.title: Gradient
content.tooltip: Accepts any valid CSS gradient function.

content.title: Background Image
content.tooltip: Insert the relative path to your image file.

content.title: Background Size
content.tooltip: The size of the background (e.g., 'cover', 'contain', '200px').

content.title: Background Position
content.tooltip: The position of the background (e.g., 'center center', 'top left').

content.title: Background Attachment
content.tooltip: The background attachment of the overlay.

content.title: Background Repeat
content.tooltip: The background repeat of the overlay.

content.title: Background Blur
content.tooltip: The backdrop blur effect for the overlay (e.g., '10px', '20px').

content.title: Overlay Opacity
content.tooltip: The opacity of the entire overlay element (0-1).

content.title: Blend Mode
content.tooltip: The CSS blend mode for the overlay.

content.title: Border Radius
content.tooltip: The border radius of the overlay (e.g., '10px', '50%', '10px 20px').

content.title: Inset
content.tooltip: The inset of the overlay (e.g., '0', '10px', '10px 20px'). The default of '0' will make the overlay cover the entire element.

content.text: If your overlay supports animation, you can animate it here. Your keyframes for the animation must be defined in custom CSS.

content.title: Animation
content.tooltip: Any valid CSS animation property. This will animate the overlay as long as you've defined your animation keyframes in custom CSS.

content.text: You can add a nested overlay to your overlay that won't affect foreground elements. This can be used to create complex overlay effects.

content.title: Nested Overlay
content.tooltip: Must be a linear gradient function! Use transparency values to make sure the nested overlay blends with your original overlay.
